935 <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="norm">bhakṣa-bhojana</lem><rdg wit="#A">baksyabvajña</rdg><rdg wit="#B">bakṣyagvajana</rdg><rdg wit="#C">baksyabhvejana</rdg></app></term>,
. <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem wit="#C" rend="hyphenright">kuṭila</lem><rdg wit="#A">kutrala</rdg><rdg wit="#B">kutrila</rdg></app>viveka</term>,
. <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="conj">matta</lem><rdg wit="#A #B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app></term>.</p>
.
. <p xml:id="siksaGuru_10.02">kaliṅanya, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">supta</term> ṅaranya, bvat turu, katuron tumakonakəna
940 <app><lem wit="#A">kaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> hayu, mvaṅ viśeṣaniṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">janmanya</lem><rdg wit="#C">janya</rdg></app>, katuron ta
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">gumavayakəna</lem><rdg wit="#A" cause="morphological">maṁgavayakna</rdg></app> enak ambək,
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">mvaṅ mujarakna hayu ri paḍanya janma</lem><rdg wit="#C"><gap reason="lost"/></rdg></app>, bhaya ṅaranya,
. <app><lem wit="#C">vədi</lem><rdg wit="#A">vda-vda</rdg><rdg wit="#B">vḍə vḍə</rdg></app> tumakonakən
945 <app><lem type="norm">hitāvasānaniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">hintavasaniṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B">tartavasaniṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#C">hitavasaniṁ</rdg></app> janma,
. <app><lem wit="#C">vədi</lem><rdg wit="#A">vda</rdg><rdg wit="#B">vḍə</rdg></app> sevaka ri tuha<pb edRef="#A" n="20r"/>nya,
. <app><lem wit="#C">vədi</lem><rdg wit="#A">vda</rdg><rdg wit="#B">vḍə</rdg></app> ri ujar rahayu,
. <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="norm">tandrī</lem><rdg wit="#A">tarḍra</rdg><rdg wit="#B">tan·dri</rdg><rdg wit="#C">tanri</rdg></app></term> ṅaranya, luhya tu<pb edRef="#C" n="19v"/>makonakəna puṅguṅnya, luhya
. <app><lem wit="#A">gumavay</lem><rdg wit="#B">magavey·</rdg><rdg wit="#C">magaveya</rdg></app> enak ambək, mvaṅ
950 <app><lem wit="#A #C">mujarak<pb edRef="#B" n="29v"/>na</lem><rdg wit="#B">ṅujarakəna</rdg></app> hayu, ya
. <app><lem type="norm">tandrī</lem><rdg wit="#A">tarḍra</rdg><rdg wit="#B">tan·dri</rdg><rdg wit="#C">tanri</rdg></app> ṅaranya,
. <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem wit="#C">kleda</lem><rdg wit="#A">kleḍra</rdg><rdg wit="#B">kelaḍa</rdg></app></term> ṅaranya, jrih gumavayakna enak ambək, jrih
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">tumakonakəna</lem><rdg wit="#C">lumakvanakən</rdg></app>
. <app><lem type="emn">hitāvasānaniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A #B #C">hintavasaniṁ</rdg></app> janma,
955 <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="emn">lajjā</lem><rdg wit="#A #C">lajña:</rdg><rdg wit="#B">lajña</rdg></app></term> ṅaranya, eraṅ-eraṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">tumakonakəna</lem><rdg wit="#B">kumakvanakna</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">kapuṅguṅnya</lem><rdg wit="#B #C">puṁguṁnya</rdg></app>, eraṅ sevaka ri tuhanya,
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">eraṅ sevaka deniṅ sukhanya</lem><rdg wit="#B"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">rāgastrī</term> ṅaranya, viṣaya harəp maṅrabi, mvaṅ harəp sukha, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">paradāra</term> ṅaranya, ṅalap estri laraṅan, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">bhakṣabhojana</term>* ṅaranya, dr̥pta maṅanuṅgalakən kinabelan, kuṭila viveka ṅaranya, <pb edRef="#A" n="20v"/>hələm gumavayakəna inak ambək mvaṅ mujarakəna hayu ri paḍanya janma, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">matta</term> ṅaranya, avərə deniṅ sukhanya, avərə deniṅ prajñānya, avərə deniṅ paṅavruhnya, averə deniṅ guṇanya, ya <term xml:lang="san-Latn">matta</term> ṅaranya, babadan hilaṅakəna ikaṅ ambək yan maṅkana denta.
.
960 </p>
. <listApp type="parallels">
. <app>
. <note corresp="Slo_84j.2">Slo 84j.2: <foreign>nihan ambək daśa-mala ṅa, tan yogya ulahakna, lvirnya, tandrī, kleda, ləja, kuhaka, metraya, məgata, rāga strī, kuṭila, bhakṣabhuvana, [kimburu]. tandrī ṅa vvaṅ suṅkanān, ləson baləbəh səmpənəh adoh iṅ rahayu, aṅhiṅ hala juga kaharəpnya. kleda ṅa ambək aṅələmələm, meraṅan mariṅ harəp, tan katəkan pinakṣanya. ləja ṅa ambək tamah, agə̄ṅ tṛṣṇā, agə̄ṅ lulut asih, mariṅ hala. kuṭila ṅa parachidra, pesta peda riṅ kavəlas asih, pramāda pracale, nor ana vvaṅ den keriṅi. kuhaka ṅa ambək krodha, agə̄ṅ runtik, capalaśabda, baṅgaporaka. metraya ṅa bisāgave ujar mahala, sikaradumikara, vivikiviveka, sapa kadi sira, botārṣā rabiniṅ arabi, tan hana ulahnya rahayu, yan mətu śabdanyārūm amanis aṅhiṅ hala ri daləm, tan papilih buddhi cavuh, kāla ri hatinya, purikan. rāgastrī ṅa bahud lañji vavadonən, rambaṅ panon, bhakṣabhuvana aṇḍəṇḍa sasamaniṅ tumuvuh, akirya riṅ vvaṅ sādhu, ardeṅ paṅan inum, haṅkāra śabda prəṅkaṅ. kimburu ṅa aṅhiṅ gavene akiryakirya drəveniṅ vvaṅ sādhu, tan papilih, nor kadaṅ sānak mitra, yata memet drəveniṅ saṅ viku. maṅkana kramaniṅ daśa-mala, tan rahayu</foreign>. Cf. also SMG 6.3.</note>
. </app>
965 </listApp>
. </div>
. <div type="chapter" n="11" xml:id="siksaGuru_11">
. <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">Ten Perfections (a)</head>
. <p xml:id="siksaGuru_11.01"><term xml:lang="san-Latn">kurvanti
970 <app><lem type="emn">kr̥tāyām</lem><rdg wit="#A">kata ya</rdg><rdg wit="#B">kata yan</rdg><rdg wit="#C">tata yan</rdg></app> dharma</term>, gavayakəna sakagavayan saṅ hyaṅ dharma,
. lvirnya ta nihan, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">dāna</term>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">śīla</term>,
. <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="emn">kṣānti</lem><rdg wit="#A">yanti</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">kyanti</rdg></app></term>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">vīrya</term>,
. <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="emn">dhyāna</lem><rdg wit="#A #B #C">byana</rdg></app></term>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">prajñā</term>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">karuṇā</term>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">muditā</term>,
. <app><lem type="norm"><term xml:lang="san-Latn">metrī</term></lem><rdg wit="#A #C">metri</rdg><rdg wit="#B">mes·tri</rdg></app>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">upekṣā</term>.
975
. </p>
. <listApp type="parallels">
. <app>
. <note corresp="KAS_10§17">AS 10§17: <foreign>ikaṅ metrī karuṇā muditā upekṣā, ya tikā sinaṅguh caturpāramitā ṅaranya. papupulni caturpāramitā mvaṅ ṣaṭpāramitā, lvirnya: dāna, śīla, kṣānti, vīrya, dhyāna, prajñā, metrī, karuṇā, muditā, upekṣā. ya tikā sinaṅguh daśa-pāramitā ṅaranya, ya tikā matattva pañca-devī</foreign>. Cf. SMG 27.1.</note>
980 </app>
. </listApp>
.
. <p xml:id="siksaGuru_11.02">kaliṅanya, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">dāna</term> ṅaranya, <foreign xml:lang="osn-Latn">mere</foreign> enak ambək <foreign xml:lang="osn-Latn">di</foreign>
. <app><lem type="norm">paḍanya</lem><rdg wit="#A #C">padanya</rdg><rdg wit="#B">panya</rdg></app> janma, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">śīla</term> ṅaranya,<pb edRef="#B" n="35r"/> <app><lem wit="#A #C">vihikan</lem><rdg wit="#B">kan·</rdg><note><ptr target="#B"/> is incoherent, jump from 30r to 35r.</note></app> aṅalap kasor,
985 <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="norm">kṣānti</lem><rdg wit="#A">santi</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">sanḍi</rdg></app></term> ṅaranya, vi<pb edRef="#A" n="21r"/>hikan
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">anupakṣama</lem><rdg wit="#C">hacupakṣama</rdg></app>, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">vīrya</term> ṅaranya,
. <app><lem type="emn">utsāha</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ukṣaha</rdg><rdg wit="#B">Ukṣaya</rdg><rdg wit="#C">hukṣaha</rdg></app> ri
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">kagavayaniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#C">kagaravayavi</rdg></app> hayu,
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">tambəhana</lem><rdg wit="#C">kambhəhan</rdg></app> hayunya muvah,
990 <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="norm">dhyāna</lem><rdg wit="#A">byana</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">dyana</rdg></app></term> ṅaranya, umiṅətakən
. <app><lem type="emn">antaraniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">Artaraniṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B">an·tarana</rdg><rdg wit="#C">hantara:na</rdg></app> paramārtha, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">prajñā</term> ṅaranya,
. <app><lem type="norm">utsāha</lem><rdg wit="#A #B">Ukṣaha</rdg><rdg wit="#C">Utṣaha</rdg></app> ri kahilaṅaniṅ
. <app><lem type="norm">daśa-kleśa</lem><rdg wit="#A">ḍasakalesa</rdg><rdg wit="#B">dasaklesa</rdg><rdg wit="#C">masaklesa</rdg></app> ri śarīranya, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">karuṇā</term> ṅaranya,
. <app><lem type="norm">larā<pb edRef="#B" n="35v"/>mbək<pb edRef="#C" n="20v"/>nyāmaṅguhakən</lem><rdg wit="#A">larambhaknyamaguḥhakən·</rdg><rdg wit="#B">larambhək·nya, maṁguḥ</rdg><rdg wit="#C"><unclear>laraməta</unclear>nyamaṁguḥ</rdg></app>
995 <app><lem type="norm">duhkhaniṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">ḍukaniṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">duka Ikaṁ</rdg></app> len, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">muditā</term> ṅaranya, tar kepvan masukha
. <app><lem type="emn">riṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">niṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> len,
. <term xml:lang="san-Latn"><app><lem type="norm">metrī</lem><rdg wit="#A">metra</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">metri</rdg></app></term> ṅaranya, vruh gumavayakəna
. *<app><lem type="emn">nimittaniṁ</lem><rdg wit="#A">mimitiniṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">mimitaniṁ</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A">dadi inak</lem><rdg wit="#B">dadi, niṁ Inak</rdg><rdg wit="#C"><unclear>dadana Inak</unclear></rdg></app> ambhəknikaṅ len, <term xml:lang="san-Latn">upekṣā</term> ṅaranya, tar
1000 <app><lem type="emn">grah iri</lem><rdg wit="#A #C">gr̥h iri</rdg><rdg wit="#B">vrəh iri</rdg></app> hala hayu.</p>
. <listApp type="parallels">
. <app>
. <note corresp="SMG_27.02"><ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasamaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_27.02">Cf. SMG 27.2</ref>.</note>
. </app>
1005 </listApp>
. </div>
.
. <div type="chapter" n="12" xml:id="siksaGuru_12">
. <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">Ten Grounds (i)</head>
1010 <p xml:id="siksaGuru_12.01"><term>kurvanti <app><lem type="norm">kuśalam mahat</lem><rdg wit="#A #C">kusulamahat·</rdg><rdg wit="#B">kusalaḥ mahat·</rdg></app></term>,
. <app><lem wit="#C">gavayakəna taṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">gavayakna kaṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B">gavayak·ta</rdg></app> kuśala viśeṣa, kuśala viśeṣa ṅaranya,<pb edRef="#B" n="36r"/> asih bhakti prayatna, gorava
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">duga-du<pb edRef="#A" n="21v"/>ga</lem><rdg wit="#C">dugaga</rdg></app>, śānta karuṇa ika,
. <app><lem type="norm">anumoda, anumāna</lem><rdg wit="#A">Anumana Anumvaḍa</rdg><rdg wit="#B">Anumoda, Anumana</rdg><rdg wit="#C">hanumoda, hanumana</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem type="emn">ālambana</lem><rdg wit="#A">Aliba</rdg><rdg wit="#B">AL̥bana</rdg><rdg wit="#C">ha2bana</rdg></app>
1015 <app><lem type="emn">atvaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">AtiAṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B">Atyaṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#C">hatyəṁ</rdg></app>, ya ta sinaṅguh daśa-bhūmi ṅaranya, abhyāsa
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">lagi-lagi</lem><rdg wit="#B">lagi-lagaṁ</rdg></app> saṅ paṇḍita, ikaṅ ambək
. <app><lem type="norm">maṅkana</lem><rdg wit="#A #B #C">makana</rdg></app>.</p>
. <listApp type="parallels">
. <app>
1020 <note corresp="SMG_28.02"><ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasamaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_28.02">SMG 28.2</ref>.</note>
. </app>
. </listApp>
. </div>
.
1025 <div type="chapter" n="13" xml:id="siksaGuru_13">
. <head type="editorial" xml:lang="eng">Origins of Sorrow</head>
. <p xml:id="siksaGuru_13.01">ndah nihan kayatnakəna
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">saṅ sevaka</lem><rdg wit="#A">sa seva</rdg></app> dharma, marapvan tar
. <app><lem wit="#C">kəna riṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">knaniṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#B">kina ri</rdg></app><pb edRef="#C" n="21r"/> upadrava, jagat
1030 <app><lem wit="#B #C" rend="hyphenright">gati</lem><rdg wit="#A">ganti</rdg></app><pb edRef="#B" n="36v"/>saṅsāra, hana saṅ hyaṅ
. <app><lem type="norm">trikāyopaśānta</lem><rdg wit="#A">pasanta</rdg><rdg wit="#B">trikayvapasan·ta</rdg><rdg wit="#C">trikayopasanta</rdg></app>, śabda paśānta, ulah
. <app><lem type="norm">paśānta</lem><rdg wit="#A #B">pasanta</rdg><rdg wit="#C">pasana</rdg></app>, ambək paśānta, ya rakṣa pahayu juga, marapvan tar kəna saṅka ri duhkha, kaliṅanya, duhkha saṅka ri
. <app><lem type="norm">bhuta</lem><rdg wit="#A">buta</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">vuta</rdg></app>, duhkha saṅka ri devata, duhkha
. <app><lem wit="#A">saṅka ri</lem><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> śarīra.</p>
1035
. <p xml:id="siksaGuru_13.02" xml:lang="osn-Latn"><foreign>kaliṅanya, yan kita kəna
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">ku na</lem><rdg wit="#C">ku</rdg></app> upadrava, ku na pañca-mahabuta, pati disa<pb edRef="#B" n="37r"/>ntok oray, dipanah gəlap,
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">disaṅgu<pb edRef="#A" n="22r"/>t</lem><rdg wit="#A">disagut</rdg></app> buhaya,
. <app><lem type="norm">katiṅgaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A #B #C">katigaṁ</rdg></app> paṅpuṅ,
1040 <app><lem wit="#A">dirontok mauṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, pati dipraṅ, dihadaṅ,
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">dipuuk</lem><rdg wit="#A">dipuAk·</rdg></app>, pati labuh ti
. <app><lem wit="#A">na</lem><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> luhur kai, ditumpu,
. <app><lem wit="#A">pati dikəndat</lem><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, sakvehniṅ bajra, pati di
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">papraṅan</lem><rdg wit="#A">praṁṅan·</rdg></app>, ya duka saṅka ri buta ṅaranya,
1045 <app><lem wit="#A #B">ya</lem><rdg wit="#C">yan·</rdg></app> duka saṅka ri

. <app><lem wit="#A">səkət</lem><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, nirisan, riət hulu, sakit mata, ja<pb edRef="#B" n="37v"/>roṅən,
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">sumbilaṅən</lem><rdg wit="#C">subilaṁṅən·</rdg></app>, buyan,
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">mədu</lem><rdg wit="#C">mtu</rdg></app>, panas tiris,
1050 <app><lem wit="#A">lara hati,</lem><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app> ya duka saṅka ri
. <app><lem wit="#C">devata</lem><rdg wit="#A #B">deva</rdg></app> ṅaranya, ya duka
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">sarira</lem><rdg wit="#A">saṁka riṁ sarira</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">ṅaranya</lem><rdg wit="#A">ma</rdg></app>, pecak, beṅo,
. <app><lem type="norm">sombeṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><rdg wit="#B">svam·beṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#C">sobeṁ</rdg></app>,
1055 <app><lem wit="#B #C">buntuṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">buntaṁ</rdg></app>, buta tuli, beaṅ,

. <app><lem wit="#A #B">ya</lem><rdg wit="#C">yan</rdg></app> duka

1060 <app><lem wit="#B">pavataṅan</lem><rdg wit="#A">mavataṁṅan·</rdg><rdg wit="#C">paṁvataṁṅan·</rdg></app>, di<pb edRef="#B" n="38r"/>pisuku, dipitaṅan, mo
. <app><lem wit="#A">visesa</lem><rdg wit="#B" cause="lexical">bisa</rdg><rdg wit="#C">basa</rdg></app> di huripnya, di bənaṅnya, di gunanya, ya duka
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">kunaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">ku na</rdg></app> tribvana ṅaranya, ya duka kunaṅ bvanaloka
. <app><lem type="emn">ma ṅaranya</lem><rdg wit="#A">ma, ṅa,</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, kahuruan
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">dayəh</lem><rdg wit="#B">dayiḥ</rdg></app>, buruṅ tahun, eleh dayəh, eleh ku sasalad<pb edRef="#C" n="22r"/>, laru salah masa,

. <listApp type="parallels">

. <p xml:id="siksaGuru_13.03" xml:lang="osn-Latn"><foreign>ma<pb edRef="#B" n="38v"/>na duka ku ulahta, ku
. <app><lem type="emn">sabdanta</lem><rdg wit="#A #C">sabdanya</rdg><rdg wit="#B">sabḍanya</rdg></app>, ku

1075 <app><lem wit="#A">ñumpah-madahkən</lem><rdg wit="#B #C">ñumpaḥ</rdg></app>,

. <app><lem wit="#B #C">guru</lem><rdg wit="#A">naru</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#C">capala</lem><rdg wit="#A" cause="lexical">capəlak</rdg><rdg wit="#B">campala</rdg></app> sabda, gasoṅ tan pakarana,
1080 <app><lem wit="#A #C">ya</lem><rdg wit="#B">ya sinaṁguḥ</rdg></app> sabda dusta ṅaranya, ulah dusta ṅaranya, nam<pb edRef="#B" n="39r"/>par, mərəp, ṅadədəl, nəvək,
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">notok</lem><rdg wit="#A"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg></app>, mokol, sakvehniṅ ləkas taṅan, ya ulah dusta ṅaranya, ambək dusta ṅaranya, ṅaracun, mijahətan, hiri payogya, di padanya janma, ya ambə<pb edRef="#C" n="22v"/>k dusta ṅaranya, ya saṅkaniṅ
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">duka</lem><rdg wit="#B"/></app> ku ulahta, ku sabdata, ku ambəkta.</foreign></p>
.
. <p xml:id="siksaGuru_13.04">kita
1085 <app><lem type="emn">yan avədi</lem><rdg wit="#A">yan:avda</rdg><rdg wit="#B">yan· vədu</rdg><rdg wit="#C">yan vdi</rdg></app> ri upa<pb edRef="#B" n="39v"/>drava, ulahakən śabda paśānta
. <app><lem type="norm">ṅaranya, ulah paśānta</lem><rdg wit="#A">ṅa, Ulaḥ pasanta</rdg><rdg wit="#B"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><rdg wit="#C">ṅaranya, Ulaḥ pasanta</rdg></app>, ambək paśānta,
. <app><lem wit="#C">ya ta</lem><rdg wit="#A"><gap reason="omitted"/></rdg><rdg wit="#B">ya</rdg></app> kayatnakəna saṅ sevaka dharma, marapvan tan vinigraha, śabda paśānta ṅaranya, śabda menak, śabda rahayu, śabda <pb edRef="#A" n="23v"/> manohara, śabda
. <app><lem type="norm">madavā</lem><rdg wit="#A">maḍava</rdg><rdg wit="#B">mandava</rdg><rdg wit="#C">madava</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem type="norm">śabda manis arum, ya śabda paśānta ṅaranya</lem><rdg wit="#A">sabda manisa:rum·, ya sabda pasanta, ṅa</rdg><rdg wit="#B">sabḍa manis arum·, vulat ma2hara, mere Enak ambhək:aṁ rat·, ya sabḍa pasan·ta ṅaranya</rdg><rdg wit="#C">sabḍa manis arum·, ya sabḍa pasan·ta ṅaranya</rdg></app>, ulah paśānta ṅaranya, ulah menak, ulah
1090 <app><lem wit="#A #C">rahayu,</lem><rdg wit="#B">rahayu, Ulaḥ yukti,</rdg></app> hayva palar
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">cidra</lem><rdg wit="#C">cin·da</rdg></app>, hayva
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">praṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">sraṁ</rdg></app>, ulah
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">rahayu</lem><rdg wit="#A">hala hayu:</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">taṅan</lem><rdg wit="#B">taṁṅan· taṁṅan</rdg></app>
1095 <app><lem wit="#A #C">masaṅguli</lem><rdg wit="#B">masaṁguliṁ</rdg></app>, matalaṅkup, yan paṅucap lavan
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">vvaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#B">ṣaṁ vvaṁ</rdg></app> atuha, ya ulah paśānta ṅaranya, ambək
. <app><lem type="norm">paśānta</lem><rdg wit="#A #B">pasanta</rdg><rdg wit="#C">pasta</rdg></app> ṅaranya, hayva
. <app><lem type="emn">daṇḍakara</lem><rdg wit="#A">ḍaḍakara</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">dadakara</rdg></app>,
. <app><lem wit="#A #B">hiri payogya</lem><rdg wit="#C">hira yogya</rdg></app>, ri paḍanya <pb edRef="#C" n="23r"/> janma, hayva <pb edRef="#B" n="40v"/>
1100 <app><lem wit="#A #B">jahət</lem><rdg wit="#C">jahat·</rdg></app> ambək, ṅahanakən
. <app><lem type="norm">ambək</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ambhak·</rdg><rdg wit="#B #C">Ambhək·</rdg></app> menak<supplied reason="omitted">,</supplied>
. <app><lem wit="#C">ambək</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ambhak</rdg><rdg wit="#B">Ambhək·</rdg></app> heraṅ,
. <app><lem type="norm">ambek</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ambak</rdg><rdg wit="#B">Ambhək·</rdg><rdg wit="#C">Ambhək·</rdg></app> rahayu, ya
. <app><lem wit="#C">ambək</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ambhak</rdg><rdg wit="#B">Ambhək</rdg></app> paśānta ṅaranya,
1105 <app><lem wit="#B">yan</lem><rdg wit="#A">ya</rdg><rdg wit="#C">yana</rdg></app>
. <app><lem wit="#A #C">karasa</lem><rdg wit="#B">kurasa</rdg></app> ikaṅ paśānta,
. <app><lem type="norm" rend="hyphenright">kahanakən sakāya</lem><rdg wit="#A">kahanakən sakaya</rdg><rdg wit="#B">kayatnakənnikaṁ</rdg><rdg wit="#C">kahanakən:ikaṁ</rdg></app>-kāyikadharma, yan tan karasa
. <app><lem wit="#B #C">i<pb edRef="#A" n="24r"/>kaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">Iririkaṁ</rdg></app> paśānta,
. <app><lem wit="#B">ambək</lem><rdg wit="#A">Ambhak·</rdg><rdg wit="#C">Ambhək·</rdg></app> duṣṭa

. <listApp type="parallels">
. <app>
. <note corresp="SMG_20.04"><ref target="DHARMA_CritEdSasamaMahaguru.xml#sasanaMahaguru_20.04">Cf. SMG 20.4–6</ref>.</note>
. </app>

.
. </div>
. <div xml:id="siksaGuru_14">
. <ab xml:id="siksaGuru_14.01" type="colophon"><app>
1120 <lem wit="#C">iti śikṣā guru ṅaranira.</lem>
. <rdg wit="#A">nihan sikṣa saṁ pandita, sikṣa guru, ṅa, ya ta mataṅyan kayatnakna saṁ sevaka ḍarmma, ø <lb n="24r2"/>//,//, Iti siksa guru, ṅa,</rdg>
. <rdg wit="#B">Itiḥ sikṣa saṁ pandita, nihan ṣikṣa guru ṅaranya, yan mataṁṅyan kayatnakna saṁ sevaka darma, tman·///ø///</rdg>
. </app>
. </ab>
1125 </div>
. </div>
. <div type="translation">
. <div n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_01">
. <p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.01">I will first teach the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> as follows. You will succeed in listening to the discerning of the holy <foreign>dharma</foreign> and the firm state of the holy gnosis. There is what is called the pure circle of three bodily domains,<note><foreign>trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha</foreign>: On the concept of the pure circle of three bodily domains, see Chapter 10, §Dharma and Three Bodily Domains.</note> uttered by the teacher to the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>. Look, I would say they are the action, speech, and mind. If there is filth in your heart,<note>The emendation of <foreign>pr̥dayanta</foreign> into <foreign>hr̥dayanta</foreign> is easily justifiable on palaeographic grounds (the similarity of <foreign>aksara pa</foreign> and <foreign>ha</foreign>).</note> it is they that should be given full attention and restrained. Guard them very well, for they are the causes of finding joy and sorrow, good and bad.</p>
1130
. <p n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.02">If your action, your speech and your mind are unrighteous, in that case you surely obtain the wrong. If your action, your speech, and your heart are righteous, in that case it is clear that you obtain the virtue. That is why there is a proverb “Thus as one repeatedly baths, the water is touched by the inherent nature of the human: bad meets its bad, good meets its good”.<note>The water metaphor also occurs in SKK 16.</note> Likewise is human nature.</p>
.
. <p n="3" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.03">What are the illustrations with regard to the consequence of this, <supplied reason="subaudible">namely</supplied>: bad from its bad, good from its good? As follows is your analogy:<note>I consider the word <foreign>upadyanta</foreign> to be derived from Skt. <foreign>upādhi</foreign> ‘what is put in the place of another thing, substitute; anything that has the mere appearance, disguise, peculiarity, attribute; limitation, qualification, condition, postulate’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>upadi</foreign>). In this text, it seems that this word is an equivalent of <foreign>lvir</foreign>, so I interpret it as ‘analogy, allusion’.</note> there is what is called the priceless jewel, its value can not be known, being incomparable<note><foreign>tan paprameya</foreign> is denazalitation of <foreign>maprameya</foreign>, which is not recorded in OJED, but it seems to have the same meaning as <foreign>aprameya</foreign> ‘immeasurable, countless, unfathomable, incomparable, indescribable, without equal’ (OJED, s.v.).</note>
. in terms of beauty. The meaning is: the priceless jewel and the most coveted jewel. Is it fitting to be bound to bell-metal, copper, and tin by you? What is the appropriateness <supplied reason="subaudible">of such a condition</supplied>? It is evident that if its splendor and its shine come out, then your binding for the priceless jewel and your tieing for the most coveted gem in such a manner are appropriate.</p>
1135
. <p n="4" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.04">These are the words of the holy treatise: <q><foreign>ləpas ca vuṅkunuṅ ceva, adhika udika tatte tatur tathya tuṅgəṅ</foreign>.</q> This is proclaimed (<foreign>etad eva nigadyate</foreign>).<note><foreign>ləpas ca vuṅkunuṅ ceva, adhika udika tatte tatur tathya tuṅgəṅ, tad eva nigaḍyate</foreign>: this “hybrid Sanskrit” passage is really obscure and could not be traced to its source. It is clear that this passage is not entirely in Sanskrit but a mixture of Sanskrit and Old Javanese. The word <foreign>ləpas</foreign> means ’release’; <foreign>vuṅkunuṅ</foreign> only appears in <foreign>pavuṅkunuṅ</foreign>, recorded among the list of <foreign>vatək i jro</foreign>. The reading of msC is <foreign>buṅ kuniṅ</foreign> ‘yellow bamboo’ which is more understandable in meaning, although it is difficult to reconcile with the present context. The word <foreign>adhika</foreign> means ‘superior, eminent, excellent’, but <foreign>udika</foreign> is obscure; <foreign>tatte</foreign> (<foreign>tattve</foreign>?) and <foreign>tathya</foreign> probably convey the meaning of ‘true, truth’, and are probably attributes of <foreign>tatur</foreign> ‘gold’. The word <foreign>tuṅgəṅ</foreign> means ‘steadfast, firm, unmoved, unshaken’. The general meaning of this excerpt that I can guess based on the OJ exegesis is the statement that hair is unsuitable as the binding of a jewel.</note> Because what is considered loose hair is square hair (? <foreign>vulu pasagi</foreign>); there is the <foreign>uḍika</foreign>, the <foreign>tater</foreign>, and the lice.<note> <foreign>sorasa</foreign>: this word is not recorded in OJED, but probably it refers to Skt. <foreign>saurasa</foreign> ‘a partic. insect infesting the hair’ (MW, s.v.).</note> Are all of them appropriate to be bound to the priceless jewel and chained to the most coveted jewel? No, it is not like that; they should be bound to the bell-metal, copper, and tin. Why is that appropriate? The binding to the priceless jewel, the chaining to the most coveted jewel, these are the words of the holy treatise: <q><foreign>ləpas ca vuṅkunuṅ ceva, adhika udika tatte tatur tathya tuṅgəṅ nu yogyanika</foreign></q>.</p>
.
. <p n="5" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.05">There is what is called the glowing gold,<note><foreign>santaṅva</foreign>: this word is not recorded in OJED, but it is found in Old Sundanese SMG 21.3 <foreign>santaṅva</foreign>. My interpretation ‘glowing’ is based on the interchangeability of <foreign>v</foreign> and <foreign>p</foreign> of the Skt. word <foreign>santāpa</foreign> ‘burning heat, glow, fire’ (OJED, s.v.).</note>
. beautiful gold; its value is one <foreign>kati</foreign>. The course of action<note><foreign>vrəttya</foreign> is my conjectural emendation of <foreign>vrət</foreign> in msA msB and <foreign>vr(uḥ)nya</foreign> in msC. I render it as an irrealis of <foreign>vr̥tti</foreign> ‘mode of being, nature, kind, activity, function; complex formation, compound, style of composition, mode of life, conduct; mode of being, nature.’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>vr̥tti</foreign>).</note> will be <supplied reason="subaudible">as follows</supplied>: it is mixed seven times seven <supplied reason="subaudible">times</supplied>,<note><foreign>inapisan pituṅ apitu</foreign>: the word <foreign>inapisan</foreign> is not recorded in the OJED. It is probably an -<foreign>in</foreign>- form of the second base of <foreign>apisan</foreign> ’to be one, to be united, joined’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>pisan</foreign>). However, I did not find the passive <foreign>inapisan</foreign> in the OJ corpus accessible to me. I do not exclude the possibility of emending it to <foreign>linapisan</foreign> ‘to be layered’. The following combination, <foreign>pituṅ apitu</foreign>, is also not found in the corpus. My translation ‘seven times seven [times]’ is tentative.</note>
1140 transforming into the weight of one <foreign>tahil</foreign> of stone. How can it be strong, not undulating, unwavering, when it is set ablaze again? For only in this way is the best quality of all the gold, and then your binding of priceless jewels and your tying of the most coveted jewel are appropriate and good.</p>
. <p n="6" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.06">It <supplied reason="subaudible">i.e. gold</supplied> is bound with bell-metal, copper, and tin, its splendor and its shine are not coming out. What are the reasons why they are not appropriate? Wrong innate <supplied reason="subaudible">disposition</supplied>, wrong karma, wrong nature. Just so is the holy supreme <foreign>dharma</foreign>:<note>The meaning of <foreign>san hyaṅ dharma viśeṣa</foreign> is unclear; it probably refers to the personified holy soul since it is mentioned with <foreign>avakta</foreign> ‘your body’.</note> it is a priceless gem. And also your body: it is the most coveted gem.</p>
.
. <p n="7" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.07">Here is the analogy of bell-metal, copper, and tin: they are not appropriate to be bound to the priceless jewel, <supplied reason="subaudible">and be</supplied> tied by you to the most coveted jewel.</p>
.
1145 <p n="8" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.08">They are as follows: bad actions, improper speech, and impure minds towards all humans — especially toward scholars. The meaning is: bad actions, improper speech, and a dirty mind are really not appropriate; the holy <foreign>dharma</foreign> shall be reflected upon; furthermore, protect <supplied reason="subaudible">it</supplied> in your body,<note> One would expect the irrealis or imperative form in this context, so the reading could be emended to <foreign>rakṣaa</foreign>.</note> and even more so with respect to holy men.<note><foreign>saṅ paṇḍita</foreign>: besides the term <foreign>paṇḍita</foreign>, which I consistently translate as ‘scholar’, we find several synonyms to denote the teacher, one of which is <foreign>vvaṅ</foreign> <foreign>sādhu</foreign> ‘holy man; saint’, as we see in this paragraph. Another word that is also used as a synonym for <foreign>paṇḍita</foreign> is <foreign>vvaṅ atuha</foreign>.</note> No, it is not proper <supplied reason="subaudible">to have improper speech, etc.</supplied>: repeatedly your birth <supplied reason="subaudible">arises</supplied>; one stops to desire having a child, having a wife, building a family, having relatives and a mother in law. He is unable to protect <supplied reason="subaudible">himself</supplied> from bad actions, improper speech, a bad mind towards all humans, and especially towards ascetics. How would your protection of your body be appropriate? That is ‘the glowing’ (<foreign>santaṅva</foreign>) according to the scholar. It means the glowing gold: the good action, the good speech, the good heart. Those should be protected by <supplied reason="subaudible">means of</supplied> the holy <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
.
. <p n="9" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.09">As follows is the reason why it is called the pure circle of three bodily domains, according to the scholar: tri means three. The circle of three bodily domains is pure.<note>From a stylistic point of view characteristic of <foreign>tutur</foreign> genre, the explanation of the gloss <foreign>trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha</foreign> in this sentence is rather unusual. Normally, each Sanskrit term is described individually. Could it be that all manuscripts are corrupt in this passage? The description of the Old Sundanese version in SMG 20.1 for the same terminology is more elaborate than that of the SiGu.</note> So it is said. Thus are the three bodily domains, according to the scholar.</p>
.
. <p n="10" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.10">As follows is the beginning<note>The word <foreign>təmbəy</foreign> seems to be a typical OJ word in the manuscript tradition in West Java, occurring instead of the more common <foreign>tambay</foreign> or <foreign>tambe</foreign>. OS texts also have <foreign>təmbəy</foreign>. MdS only has its derived form <foreign>mitəmbəyan</foreign> ‘to start’.</note> of the affection of a scholar toward the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>. It is pure in good thought. Do it quickly! Do not be tucked in with dirty thoughts. The heart and mind are pure. Then, purify the mind and the set of your emotions! You should be aware when thinking; you should practice the activity of begging for alms (<foreign>bhikṣā-lakṣanam</foreign>)<note>The compound <foreign>bhikṣā-lakṣanam</foreign> is unattested in OJ and my translation ‘the activity of begging for alms’, which is based on the understanding of <foreign>lakṣaṇa</foreign> in its Old Javanese sense of ‘action, doing, practice’ etc. (see OJED s.v.), is tentative. Alternatively, it may be rendered as ‘the one of mendicant (<foreign>bhiksu</foreign>) character’.</note> with full attention.</p>
1150 <p n="11" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.11">Here are your characteristics, O holy man. Do not just be attached to servants. It is evident when the hair has been cut. Cut it <supplied reason="subaudible">so that</supplied> there is no obstruction or hindrance. That is the purity (<foreign>pariśuddha</foreign>): you should cut it before and you should control it. It is what is called †<foreign>r̥kr̥t</foreign>† gold, and making flower offerings with water.<note>All manuscripts have <foreign>vañva</foreign>, unattested in OJED. I consider it to be a variant of <foreign>bañu</foreign>. However, the irrealis form seems unnecessary. Or should it be read <foreign>vaño</foreign>? Or <foreign>vañva</foreign> is related to <foreign>vanua/vano</foreign> ‘inhabited land’, Mal. <foreign>benua</foreign>, and the clause needs to be read as <foreign>mas səkar vañva</foreign> ‘the gold as the flowers of country’.</note> In this manner you serve the scholar. Do not commit the sin of violating the guru’s bed (<foreign>guru-talpaka</foreign>),<note> On the term <foreign>guru-talpaka</foreign>, see chapter 10, §Footsoles of the teacher.</note> <supplied reason="subaudible">which is</supplied> a misfortune for the world; <supplied reason="subaudible">rather, you</supplied> should fear him. You should be devoted and submit to the teacher, you should carry out <supplied reason="subaudible">acts of</supplied> extreme respect toward the teacher, including scholars. <supplied reason="subaudible">In this manner you</supplied> come to the realization of that goal.</p>
. <p n="12" corresp="#siksaGuru_01.12">In this manner you are the servant of the scholar, and even more so of the king. Do not be unfaithful toward the king. <supplied reason="subaudible">You</supplied> will be fined and hated. You should be afraid of him, so that you will not be sold and die horribly. You should be loyal to the king: that is why <supplied reason="subaudible">you</supplied> come to the realization of that goal (i.e., avoiding being sold and dying). You<note>The expression <foreign>kita</foreign> ‘you’ in this sentence implies that the audience of the text involved <foreign>rāma</foreign>, <foreign>kalaṅ</foreign>, etc. Alternatively, if the word <foreign>kasādhyanya</foreign> indicates the fruit to be enjoyed rather than the realization of the goal of loyalty to the king, one could translate as follows: ‘You [will become] in this manner: an elder (<foreign>rāma</foreign>), a <foreign>kalaṅ</foreign>, a <foreign>gusti</foreign>, a vizir (<foreign>patih</foreign>) in the village (<foreign>banva</foreign>)’.</note>
. elder (<foreign>rāma</foreign>), <foreign>kalaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>gusti</foreign>, vizir (<foreign>patih</foreign>) in the village (<foreign>banva</foreign>), <supplied reason="subaudible">should behave</supplied> in this manner. Furthermore, <supplied reason="subaudible">concerning</supplied> the quality (<foreign>dharma</foreign>) of a balanced mind in people like you, you should not have an unbalanced voice<note><foreign>timpaṅ svara</foreign>: the word <foreign>timpaṅ</foreign> means ‘crippled, limp’ (OJED, s.v.). In this context of legal preceding, I interpret <foreign>timpaṅ svara</foreign> as ‘unbalanced voice’.</note> in the legal proceeding, do not lean left and right with respect to good and bad qualities. It is not appropriate <supplied reason="subaudible">as the</supplied> behavior of an experienced man, says the holy scriptures. That <supplied reason="subaudible">wrong behavior</supplied> should not be followed by you, that is the reason why <supplied reason="subaudible">if you follow it</supplied> the three domains of body and mind (<foreign>trikāya maṇḍalam cittam</foreign>) are not achieved. Then the servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should devote their full attention to what is called ‘the sacred circle of the three pure bodily domains’. It is the beginning of the affection of the scholar toward the servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
. </div>
.
1155 <div n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_02">
. <p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.01">There is a second <supplied reason="subaudible">type of</supplied> affection of the scholar toward the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>, which is called the ten rules (<foreign>daśa-śīla</foreign>).<note> About the concept of <foreign>daśa-śīla</foreign> as a term for the ten organs, see chapter 11.</note> They are the following: ears, eyes, nose, tongue, mouth, skin, hands, genitals, anus, legs. This<note>In the SiGu, the word <foreign>ini</foreign>, not recorded in OJED, is often used instead of <foreign>nihan</foreign>. This is clearly an Old Sundanese influence, since this word is very frequent in Old Sundanese texts.</note> is what the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should hear.</p>
. <p n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.02"><foreign>Śrotra</foreign> means ears. What is the sphere of the ears? They serve as a gate to hear the bad and good words. When you hear sweet and fragrant words, your heart becomes comfortable. When you hear a bad word, its fault is evidently unthinkable. Please do not repeat it. A good action for the teacher, that is what the servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> who are deaf<note>It seems that we should render <foreign>tuli</foreign> as <foreign>tuluy</foreign> ‘immediate continuation’ (see OJED s.v. <foreign>tuli</foreign> II: ‘see <foreign>tuluy</foreign>’) in this phrase. If it is the intended word, then the translation of <foreign>tuli maṅrəṅə̄ aji saṅ viku</foreign> would be ‘who should continually hear the scriptures of hermits’.</note> in hearing the scriptures of the hermit should endeavor to carry out.</p>
. <p n="3" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.03"><foreign>Cakṣuh</foreign> means eyes. What is the sphere of activity of the eyes? To see good and bad, which causes joy and sorrow. How could they (i.e., the eyes) cause joy? They serve as your instrument to see the good deeds. You are without hindrance<note>My interpretation of <foreign>laṅsar</foreign> as ‘unobstructed, without hindrance’ is based on the meaning in MdS (Hardjadibrata 2003: s.v. <foreign>langsar</foreign>), which seems to fit the context. In OJ the meaning is unclear; it may be related to <foreign>luṅsur</foreign> ‘come down, slip down’.</note> by means of that. How could that bring sorrow? From them (the eyes, <foreign>saka rika</foreign>), you should see the gold<note>All manuscripts contain the same reading, but the phrase <foreign>mulata mas</foreign> is problematic. The sentence <foreign>mulata mas ri paḍanya janma len saka rika</foreign> is problematic for several reasons. First, the phrase <foreign>mulata mas</foreign> is difficult to understand in this context. Second, while the sequence <foreign>len saka rika</foreign> occurs very often, meaning ‘other than that’, in this context, I am inclined to consider <foreign>len</foreign> as an attribute to <foreign>janma</foreign>, so <foreign>janma len</foreign> would mean ‘other people.’ Indeed, this phrase is rarely found in OJ, but it is attested in BY 15.16 <foreign>yan movaha kita janma len kakanta</foreign>. Cf. also <foreign>vvaṅ len</foreign>, a more common combination than <foreign>janma len</foreign>, occurring in Slo 30j <foreign>amaṅan ulihnya gumavayakən sakāryaniṅ vvaṅ len</foreign>.</note> of the other fellow human beings. You walk to a public place, you see people with disabilities, leprosy, invalidities, goiter, <supplied reason="subaudible">a stomach affected by</supplied> starvation (? <foreign>buḍaya</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>buḍaya</foreign> is not attested in OJED. My tentative translation is based on a guess from <foreign>budayut</foreign> in MdS ‘having a distended stomach’.</note> defolded,<note>OJED glosses <foreign>tikəl</foreign> as ‘broken (of something straight), broken in two, with a sharp bend or break (in a straight line), esp. of the line of the brows (when cross or angry)’. It is not clear which part of the body it refers to, but it seems to be the hand or the foot.</note> stiff and rigid <supplied reason="subaudible">limbs</supplied>,<note>OJED records the word <foreign>kəkəṅ</foreign> without giving the meaning. However, we find its equivalent <foreign>kəṅkəṅ</foreign> in OS SMG, referring as a kind of hand disease. I interpret it as ‘rigid’, synonymous with stiff, by comparing it with the MdS word <foreign>jengkeng</foreign> adj. ‘(unc.) stiff (like a corpse)’; <foreign>ngajengkeng</foreign> ‘stretched (stiff)’; <foreign>jejengkengan</foreign> ‘keep on stretching (of so. tormented by pain or grief)’ (Hardjadibrata 2003: s.v. <foreign>jengkeng</foreign>); also with MdJ <foreign>kêngkêng</foreign> ‘sturdy; stiff, rigid’.</note> all kinds of frightening appearance<note>I chose <foreign>bhīma-rūpa</foreign> ‘frightening appearance’ on the basis of the shared reading of msA and msB. Even though it is not attested in the OJ corpus at my disposal, this compound is attested in Skt. sources, attributed to gods, goddess, humans, and animals. However, one would expect to have <foreign>virūpa</foreign> in this context, which is often mentioned along with the list of deforemd or otherwise sick people. Cf. AgP 51.29-52.12: <foreign>virūpa krūra malina, akuru, atəhər agalak, puṇḍuṅ, maliṅ, kuḍisən; asiṅ vvaṅ melik iriya deniṅ hamə̄ niṅ avaknya</foreign>.</note> that exist in humans, let alone those who are blind and deaf of the eyes and ears. Furthermore, do not hurt somebody who has disable bodies.<note>The combination <foreign>cheda-kṣara</foreign> is not recorded in OJED. I render it as a <foreign>tatpurusa</foreign> compound formed from <foreign>cheda</foreign>, in the OJ sense of ‘injured, hurt, with a defect’ (OJED, s.v.), and Sanskrit <foreign>kṣara</foreign> (unattested in OJED), meaning ‘the body’ (MW, s.v.).</note> You should not be like that. It is called avoiding strong emotion (<foreign>caṇḍa-parihāra</foreign>),<note>I translate <foreign>caṇḍa-parihāra</foreign> as ‘avoiding strong emotion’: cf. <foreign>caṇḍa</foreign>, Skt. ‘fierce, violent, cruel , impetuous, hot, ardent with passion, passionate, angry’; <foreign>parihāra</foreign>, ‘shunning, avoiding, excluding, abandoning’ (MW, s.vv.).</note> for the innate nature and karma<note><foreign>nija-karma</foreign> seems to be a <foreign>dvandva</foreign> compound meaning ‘innate nature and karma’. See the parallel <foreign>salah nija salah karma</foreign> in SiGu1.6.</note> are not seen. Also, people hurt because of it, that is what the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should pay attention to.</p>
. <p n="4" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.04"><foreign>Grhāṇa</foreign> means nose. What is the sphere of activity of the nose? It serves as an instrument to smell fragrant scents (<foreign>surabhi</foreign>), bad smell (<foreign>asurabhi</foreign>), <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> extraordinary smell (<foreign>asādhāraṇa</foreign>).<note><foreign>asādhāraṇa</foreign> is not attested in OJED. It is from Skt. ‘extraordinary’ (MW, s.v.). In this context it means ‘strong smell, extraordinary smell’.</note> <foreign>Surabhi</foreign> means fragrant, <foreign>asurabhi</foreign> means stinky and musty <supplied reason="subaudible">odor</supplied>, <foreign>asadhāraṇa</foreign> means singed smell (<foreign>haṅit</foreign>).<note>Instead of emending <foreign>haṅit</foreign> to OJ <foreign>asaṅit</foreign> ‘with the smell of burning (singeing), burnt’, I keep the reading <foreign>haṅit</foreign>, and render it as a West Javanese spelling variant; Cf. MdS <foreign>hangit</foreign> ‘id’.</note> Therefore, the kinds of smells are three. When you smell the fragrance, your heart is happy; when you smell a stinky and musty <supplied reason="subaudible">odor</supplied>, your heart is not happy, then<note>I am inclined to consider <foreign>ya</foreign> in <foreign>ya mətu krodhanta</foreign> as an emphatic or deictic particle (OJED, s.v. <foreign>ya</foreign> 1).</note> your anger appears; that is the cause for the inappropriate speech to arise. The three bodily domains of ultimate truth (<foreign>trikāya paramārtha</foreign>)<note>For the term <foreign>trikāya paramārtha</foreign> vis à vis <foreign>trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha</foreign>, see chapter 11.</note> are not experienced. That is the reason why the sphere of the nose must be properly paid attention to and seriously cared after by the servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
1160 <p n="5" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.05"><foreign>Jihvā</foreign> means tongue. What is the sphere of activity of the tongue? It serves as an instrument of tasting<note>My emendation <foreign>paṅrasanikaṅ</foreign> ‘the instrument to taste’ is based on the common expression in the context of saḍrasa. Cf. OJ exegesis on Vr̥h 34, in which we find <foreign>paṅrasa</foreign> with <foreign>ṣaḍrasa</foreign>: <foreign>pinakapaṅrasa pakənanya yan pamukti ṣaḍrasa</foreign>. Alternatively, we could probably emend to <foreign>pamukti</foreign> which has the same meaning.</note> the six flavors, namely: salty (<foreign>lavaṇa</foreign>), spicy (<foreign>kaṭuka</foreign>), bitter (<foreign>tikta</foreign>), sour (<foreign>amla</foreign>), savory (<foreign>kaṣāya</foreign>),<note>In Sanskrit, <foreign>kaṣāya</foreign> means ‘astringent’, but the OJ exegesis gives <foreign>vuduk</foreign> as its equivalent. According to Zoetmulder, <foreign>vuduk</foreign> is ‘fat; also: sweet flavour’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>wuduk</foreign>), I take it as savory to differentiate with sweet. Cf. Mal. <foreign>gurih</foreign> ‘id.’; note also the term <foreign>nasi uduk</foreign>, a kind of dish with rice as a basic, cooked in coconut milk and multitude of spices resulting in a very fragrant and flavorful rice.</note> sweet (<foreign>madhura</foreign>). These are called the six flavors (<foreign>ṣaḍrasa</foreign>). <foreign>Lavaṇa</foreign> means salty, <foreign>kaṭuka</foreign> is spicy,<note> I take the meaning of <foreign>lada</foreign> as ‘spicy’ from OS and MdS. In OJ it means ‘pepper’, as in Proto Malayo-Polynesian.</note> <foreign>tikta</foreign> bitter, <foreign>amla</foreign> sour, <foreign>kaṣāya</foreign> savory, <foreign>madhura</foreign> sweet. Those are called the six flavors (<foreign>ṣaḍrasa</foreign>). Furthermore, they are all enjoyed by you; you will be oblivious of everything but becoming sick because of them. You shall not do so. Its object (i.e. the tongue) becomes a goal to be realized. That is a sign that you will abandon good works toward the teacher. If so, then the pure circle of three bodily domains is not experienced.</p>
. <p n="6" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.06"><foreign>Vāk</foreign> means words.<note> One would expect <foreign>tutuk</foreign> instead of <foreign>śabda</foreign>, but <foreign>śabda</foreign> as a definition of <foreign>vāk</foreign> in the context of ten organs is attested in AS 5 <foreign>ka, ikaṅ kāya, vāk, manah. kāya ṅa śarīra, solahniṅ taṅan suku, ya kāya ṅaranya. vāk ṅaranya: śabda. salvirniṅ vuvus ya śabda ṅaranya</foreign>.</note> What is the sphere of activity of the words? Not every word should be followed by you: harsh words <supplied reason="subaudible">equal</supplied> aggressive behavior.<note><foreign>capala asta</foreign> ‘restless hands’ seems to be out of context. In inscriptions, for example Waharu I, <foreign>vāk capala</foreign> and <foreign>capala hasta</foreign> ‘(Skt) with restless hands, rash in coming to blows, aggressive’ are listed among the <foreign>sukha-duhkha</foreign> ‘the vicissitudes of life’: <foreign>rah katəmu riṅ havan, vākcapala, hastacapala</foreign>. Should it be emended to <foreign>vāk capala</foreign>? Cf. Vr̥h 18.2: <foreign>panasbaran, lobha, capala hasta, capala pāda, vākcapala... lakṣaṇaniṅ citta si rajah</foreign>.</note> In the situation of powerlessness and in trouble, you do not make other human beings feel at ease. However, what you should speak are words that are sweet, gentle, <supplied reason="subaudible">with</supplied> an agreeable <supplied reason="subaudible">facial</supplied> gesture. All kinds of things that make them indifferent to the world, and which are heard in succession by human beings,<note>It seems that <foreign>loka para</foreign> is an equivalent of <foreign>loka parəmpara</foreign> ’uninterrupted, in succession’ (or <foreign>parampara</foreign>; see OJED, s.v. <foreign>parampara</foreign>), attested in AgP 352.21: <foreign>hana ujar yogya rəṅə̄n deniṅ loka parəmpara</foreign>; Cf RY 3.3, which mentions <foreign>parampara</foreign> after the verb <foreign>karəṅə̄</foreign>: <foreign>praśasta karəṅə̄ parampara ujar narendrāpagəh</foreign>. Alternatively, <foreign>loka para</foreign> could be considered as an equivalent of <foreign>paraloka</foreign> ‘other people’.</note> that is how you guard your words.</p>
. <p n="7" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.07"><foreign>Tvak</foreign> means skin. What is the sphere of activity of the skin? To feel and experience heat and cold. The point of this is the effort to restrain the passions<note> In this context, I render the meaning of <foreign>viṣaya</foreign> as ‘passion’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>viṣaya</foreign> 4.).</note> that emerge from the skin.</p>
. <p n="8" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.08"><foreign>Pāṇi</foreign> means hand. What is the sphere of activity of the hand? To join the fingers of the hand,<note>The phrase <foreign>masaṅguliniṅ taṅan</foreign> literally means ‘to make the fingers of hand as one’ or, in other words, ‘to join the fingers of hand’; <foreign>masaṅguli</foreign> is from <foreign>aṅguli</foreign> ‘(Skt) finger’, but the derivative form <foreign>saṅguli</foreign> and verbal form <foreign>maṅguli</foreign> are not recorded in OJED.</note> to join <supplied reason="subaudible">the hands</supplied> when talking to the teacher. Also not to join the hands together with the teacher, and especially not to point the hand toward the face of the teacher; when the food of the teacher should be grasped, it should not be touched with the mouth.<note>In OJED, <foreign>acumbana</foreign> usually means ‘making love, having sexual intercourse, united in love’, but in this context, the Sanskrit meaning ‘to kiss, to touch with the mouth’ (MW, s.v. <foreign>cumb</foreign>) seems more suitable.</note> Or, do not take the teacher’s divine-property (<foreign>drabya hyaṅ</foreign>), let alone of any <supplied reason="subaudible">kind of</supplied> people. This means do not be disloyal<note>msC has <foreign>paracidra</foreign> ‘disloyal’, while msA and msB have <foreign>palarcidra</foreign>. The latter two manuscripts seem to be influenced by the Old Sundanese. Cf. SMG 2.2 <foreign>hantə ṅənah palar cidəra ku paṅəsi huma sakalih</foreign>.</note> if he has a request. There are “sword leaves”<note>The usage of the word <foreign>āsipattra</foreign> ‘sword leaves’ in OJ is usually used in depictions of hell. Here it seems to be an allusion to the misfortune provoked by the teacher. Compare the similar expression <foreign>jagat upadrava</foreign>, one of the ‘terrifying weapon’ possessed by the teacher.</note> in the sacred texts of the hermit. Such is what you should do to guard your hands.</p>
. <p n="9" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.09"><foreign>Pāyu</foreign> means anus. What is the sphere of activity of the anus? It is circular (<foreign>utər</foreign>) and joint (<foreign>saṅga</foreign>). Defecating <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> farting <supplied reason="subaudible">as appropriate</supplied> are the ways in which you guard the anus. You should not fart in front of the teacher of men, you should not be in front of people when you defecate. <supplied reason="subaudible">These behaviors</supplied> are not ordered by the teacher, and by all the religious wanderers (<foreign>paramābhyāgata</foreign>).<note>The compound <foreign>paramābhyāgata</foreign> is not attested in OJED; it literally means ‘most respected guest’, which I interpret as a reference to a ‘religious wanderer’.</note> Such are the ways in which you should guard your anus.</p>
1165 <p n="10" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.10"><foreign>Upastha</foreign> means sexual organ. What is the sphere of activity of the sexual organ? To feel sexual pleasure <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> to urinate. The meaning is as follows: to urinate, it should not be done in front of the people, especially those of high birth: male, female, servant, noble man, low, medium, and high. Since its <foreign>maruruca</foreign> (?) is great, the sins of becoming a human being comes out. What is considered as its sins? You see a man that is sold. His sins are his <supplied reason="subaudible">way of</supplied> seizing women: misbehaving toward friends, misbehaving toward the teachers, taking by force forbidden women. The body vehemently becomes dirty if it is as such. <supplied reason="subaudible">That</supplied> must be paid attention to by the servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
. <p n="11" corresp="#siksaGuru_02.11"><foreign>Pāda</foreign> means the feet. What is the sphere of activity of the feet? To walk wherever is your destination, whether you go to the north, south, west, east, or to sit in a sila position. Then the way to guard the foot is: not kicking, not assuming an impolite posture,<note><foreign>tan paraṅkakan</foreign> ‘not assuming an impolite posture’; see OJED <foreign>aṅraṅkak</foreign> ‘to assume a bold attitude (ready for fighting)’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>raṅkak</foreign>), listing one occurrence from RY 8.61: <foreign>vvil kapvāṅraṅkak caṅciṅañ caṅka-caṅkag</foreign>. Cf. BS 105.14–106.3 <foreign>oṁ sila sila mānuṣa, sila gaṇa maheśvara, amire bhaṭāra brahmā, aṅraṅkak bhaṭāra rudra, akilusū mahādeva, aṅruṅkuk saṅ hyaṅ śaṅkara, sila pas bhaṭāra viṣṇu, atimpuh bhaṭāra śambhu, muruduṅ bhaṭāra śiva, aṅadəg i gunuṅ nāga</foreign>. Can it mean ‘to crawl’ as <foreign>merangkak</foreign> in Malay? </note> not <supplied reason="subaudible">assuming</supplied> an unstable posture,<note> The derivative form <foreign>pamagah-magahan</foreign> is not recorded in OJED. Its base, <foreign>agah-agah</foreign>, is plausibly a variant spelling from the base <foreign>haga-haga</foreign> ‘thoughtless, wild, uncontrollable’ (OJED, s.v.).</note> not to lean sideways, not to lie stretched out, not sit by dangling<note><foreign>padvaṅdaṅ</foreign> is not recorded in OJED, but the meaning from MdS <foreign>dongdang</foreign>, <foreign>sidongdang</foreign> ‘sit with both legs dangling to one side’ seems to be appropriate in the present context.</note> the leg in front of the teacher, <supplied reason="subaudible">or</supplied> of all religious wanderers. This <supplied reason="subaudible">is the way</supplied> to guard the foot, <supplied reason="subaudible">which</supplied> should be made the object of full attention by the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
. </div>
.
.<div n="3" corresp="#siksaGuru_03">
1170 <p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_03.01">As follows is the third affection of the scholar to the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>. Here are the five instructions, as they are called, namely:</p>
. <p rend="stanza" corresp="#siksaGuru_03.02">Non-anger, obedience to the teacher, purity, moderation in food, and non-inattentiveness are the five known as particular commandments.</p>
. <p n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_03.03">Non-anger (<foreign>akrodho</foreign>) means: it doesn’t happen that a servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> shows his anger in front of the teacher, let alone to all good men. Obedience to the teacher (<foreign>guruśuśruṣā</foreign>) means that you are devoted and obedient to the teacher, never far from the feet of the elders. <supplied reason="subaudible">It should be</supplied> that way if there is an order from the teacher. Furthermore, <supplied reason="subaudible">you should be</supplied> completely pure: the highest reality of three bodily domains should be made the object of your attention, that is good act, good speech, good thought. The pure circle of three bodily domains, together with the ten rules and the five instructions should be made the object of your efforts whether <supplied reason="subaudible">you are</supplied> far or near. Thus is called the obedience to the master. Purity (<foreign>śauca</foreign>) is to clean your hand<note>The verbal form <foreign>masəhan</foreign> is not recorded in OJED (s.v. <foreign>vasəh</foreign>); it is probably derived from the second base <foreign>vasəhan</foreign>, and the meaning is equivalent with <foreign>masəhi</foreign> ‘to wash, cleanse, purify’.</note> when you hold the food of the teacher, let alone the properties of the scholar. Moderation in food (<foreign>āhāralāghava</foreign>) <supplied reason="subaudible">means</supplied> you are swift <supplied reason="subaudible">while</supplied> eating; <supplied reason="subaudible">however, if</supplied> the balls of rice are big, and <supplied reason="subaudible">your</supplied> eating quickly is uncontrolled,<note>I take the meaning of <foreign>kāmakāra</foreign> to be ‘uncontrolled’, in the light of its meaning in Skt. ‘the act of following one’s own inclinations, spontaneous deed, voluntary action, acting of one’s own free will, free will’ (MW, s.v.). This combination is not attested in the OJ corpus available to me. It is noteworthy that msC has <foreign>humarak</foreign>, being probably a mistake for <foreign>humaraka</foreign> ‘to eat’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>haraka</foreign>); however, the -<foreign>um</foreign>- form is not recorded in OJED. Another possibility is to interpret <foreign>humarak</foreign> in the light of the Sundanese usage, where <foreign>harak</foreign> means ‘pugnacious, aggressive; (dial.) greedy, covetous, acquisitive’ (Hardjadibrata 2003: s.v. <foreign>harak</foreign>). If msC contains a correct reading, then the translation would be ‘greedy when you eat quickly’.</note> don’t <supplied reason="subaudible">act</supplied> like that! That is called the belly palace (<foreign>kukṣi-pura</foreign>).<note> The sequence <foreign>kukṣi-pura</foreign> is not attested in OJED; however, each word is known in OJ.</note> How could <supplied reason="subaudible">that</supplied> be the way of eating? It is only the vital breath with control (<foreign>prāṇa sadhāraṇa</foreign>) the daily means of subsistence of one who thinks about the Holy Good. These are what are called the five instructions, which should be made the object of attention by the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
.</div>
. <div n="4" corresp="#siksaGuru_04">
1175 <p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_04.01">As follows is the fourth affection of the scholar to the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>. This is what is called the instruction of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>, here it is—the śloka about it is as follow:</p>
. <p rend="stanza" corresp="#siksaGuru_04.02">Writing, laughing, singing, yawning, and pure <supplied reason="subaudible">from</supplied> the secret of fruit (?), one shall not do in front of the teacher.</p>
. <p n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_04.03">The meaning is <supplied reason="subaudible">as follows</supplied>; <foreign>ālekhyam</foreign><note><foreign>ālekhyam</foreign>: from Skt. <foreign>ālekhya</foreign> ‘writing, drawing’ (MW, s.v.), unattested in OJ. The attested Skt. word in OJ is <foreign>ālekhana</foreign> ‘id.’.</note> means: do not write on the soil, do not write on the board, let alone on your body, when you serve the teacher, because there are those who are considered men with good characteristics, <supplied reason="subaudible">but</supplied> constantly writing their thighs when talking with the teacher; <foreign>hasitam</foreign>:<note><foreign>hasitam</foreign>: from Skt. <foreign>hasita</foreign> ‘laughing, jesting, smiling’ (MW, s.v.).</note> not to laugh in the front of the teacher, let alone to make a joke; <foreign>gītam</foreign>: not to sing—the manner of not claiming expertise,<note>All manuscripts share the reading <foreign>vijakṣaṇa</foreign> instead of the more common OJ spelling <foreign>vicakṣaṇa</foreign> ‘(Skt) sagacious, clever, wise, versed in, familiar with, expert in’. The spelling <foreign>vijaksana</foreign> is found in OS texts.</note> if it is not ordered by the teacher; <foreign>jr̥mbhanam</foreign>:<note>The Sanskrit meaning of <foreign>jr̥mbhanam</foreign> ‘yawning; stretching the limbs, slackness’ (MW, s.v.) does not fit perfectly with the OJ explanation. </note> not to express hunger <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> satiety in the front of the teacher; <foreign>kaṇṭhāravam</foreign>:<note>My conjecture <foreign>kaṇṭhāravam</foreign> is based on the similar <foreign>aksara</foreign>s of <foreign>ṭa</foreign> and <foreign>va</foreign> with <foreign>da</foreign> and <foreign>na</foreign> respectively. The meaning in Skt. is ‘roaring from the throat’ (MW, s.v. <foreign>kaṇṭhīrava</foreign>). The only way to make this passage make sense is to emend to <foreign>paṅhvab</foreign> ‘to yawn’ where the witnesses have different readings (<foreign>paṅvamka</foreign> msA, <foreign>paṅvambha</foreign> msB, <foreign>paṅomka</foreign> msC).</note> not to yawn; †<foreign>akadanəm</foreign>† do not stretch a body <supplied reason="subaudible">and emit sounds</supplied><note>The word <foreign>paṅulet</foreign> is a denazalitation of <foreign>maṅulet</foreign> means ‘to stretch (after sleep)’, cf. OS <foreign>kumuliat</foreign>, MdS <foreign>nguliat</foreign>.</note> in front of the teacher; <foreign>śuddham phalarahasyam</foreign>: not to talk in a selfish manner in the front of the teacher, let alone to pronounce the name “penis”; it is forbidden <supplied reason="subaudible">to do</supplied> so. What is called <foreign>na karotu gurumukhe</foreign>, its meaning is as follows: the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should not do <supplied reason="subaudible">that</supplied>.</p>
. <p n="3" corresp="#siksaGuru_04.04">As follows is called the instruction of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> (<foreign>dharma-śikṣā</foreign>).</p>
. <p rend="stanza" corresp="#siksaGuru_04.05"><foreign>śalākāñjanam suravile paṇadantagharsādhyasta ceva, maprayāsamagama ceva masva ceva mibuḥ, kramaviduḥ ceva nervayude uddatayudena kaləm suparigrahaste</foreign>.</p>
1180 <p n="4" corresp="#siksaGuru_04.06">The meaning is, <foreign>śalākāñjanam</foreign>: not to use eye-paint in front of the teacher, <supplied reason="subaudible">or</supplied> in front of forbidden women. <foreign>Suravile</foreign>: not to open the mouth<note>My emendation <foreign>pakrala-krala</foreign> is based on the word <foreign>karāla</foreign>, attested in OJED, from Skt. <foreign>karāla</foreign> ‘opening wide, having a gaping mouth and projecting teeth; formidable, dreadful’; <foreign>karāladaṅṣṭra</foreign> ‘having terrific teeth’.</note> wide when one talks, let alone when one sits in sila position, not to use unguent, not to use powder, if <supplied reason="subaudible">one is in</supplied> a place for the service to the teacher, let alone <supplied reason="subaudible">where</supplied> his water stream springs forth, or <supplied reason="subaudible">in</supplied> the pavilion for welcoming <supplied reason="subaudible">guests</supplied>.<note> The sentence <foreign>yan baturan saṅ guru, ṅuniveh mijil valaharnya panti, asvāgata kunaṅ</foreign> is really hard to understand and my translation “if [one is in] a place for the service to the teacher, let alone [where] his water stream springs forth, or [in] the pavilion for welcoming [guests]” is tentative.</note> <foreign>Dantagharsā</foreign>: not to chew a quid (<foreign>susur</foreign>) when you speak to the teacher. <foreign>Adhyasta</foreign>:<note>I consider Skt. <foreign>adhyasta</foreign> meaning ‘placed over, disguised, supposed’ which seems to correspond to the OJ explanation. </note> without the ornaments of the performers, <supplied reason="subaudible">of those</supplied> who play musical instruments, and <supplied reason="subaudible">of</supplied> the <foreign>kecaka</foreign> dancers.<note> The word <foreign>kecaka</foreign> (variant: <foreign>kicaka</foreign>) may denote a type of dance, or dancer. See Acri (2014: 23, fn. 40) for the interpretation of this word.</note> <foreign>Hārahataḥ</foreign>: not taking a pointed lance <supplied reason="subaudible">measuring</supplied> one <foreign>vilah</foreign>.<note>The word <foreign>savilah</foreign> as a unit is attested in KM: <foreign>hana po dene tan ahiḍep vinalərakən, riṅ rabī, anak, lavan kahula, təmbuṅən ta riṅ priṅ, savilah, yen ikaṅ kayuha, avake gitikən, yen gigire, sukune, manih tan ahiḍep, talenana hayo hasiṅsət</foreign>. Cf. MdS <foreign>sawilah</foreign> ‘id’, Mal. <foreign>bilah</foreign>.</note> <foreign>Prayāsamāgama</foreign>: not to stare at each other with a forbidden woman, let alone the wife of the teacher, <supplied reason="subaudible">not</supplied> to carry civet-cats (<foreign>luvak</foreign>) along with prey, not to occupy oneself constantly with eating and drinking in front of the teacher. That is called the instruction of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> (<foreign>dharma-śikṣā</foreign>); <supplied reason="subaudible">it</supplied> should be made the object of the attention of the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
. </div>
. <div n="5" corresp="#siksaGuru_05">
. <p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_05.01">As follows is the fifth affection of the scholar toward the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>. How is it? As follows:</p>
. <p rend="stanza" corresp="#siksaGuru_05.02"><foreign>gurutalam pravakṣyāmi mahāyānam hyatistanti, durbage hinarsabekṣaḥ sakābhyāsa praṇamyāsīt</foreign></p>
1185 <p n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_05.03">This is the foot soles of the teacher,<note>On the concept of <foreign>guru-talapakan</foreign>, see chapter 10, §Foot soles of the teacher.</note> <foreign>pravakṣyāmi</foreign>: <supplied reason="subaudible">I</supplied> will explain the sacred virtuousness. <foreign>ahāyānam hyatisṭānti</foreign> those eminent ones were in the past—Buddhist, Śivaist, servant, noble man, inferior, middle, and superior, men or women. Their aim was to collect the sacred virtuousness as a book (?, <foreign>vataṅ</foreign>).<note>My interpretation of <foreign>vataṅ</foreign> as ‘book’ is based on the occurrence of <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ hayu</foreign> in this clause. As I mentioned in Chapter 4, another designation of <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ hayu</foreign> as a title is <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ vataṅ agəṅ</foreign>, which most plausible means ‘the holy great book’. The word <foreign>vataṅ</foreign> literally means ‘1. a tree-trunk (fallen, felled), bar, piece of wood; 2. pole; a kind of lance or pike, prob. of wood or bamboo with an iron tip’ (OJED, s.v.). </note> In the first place, they were taught about the foot soless of the teacher. What is the reason? Thus: the teacher does not create misfortune. How so? The foot soles of the teacher was followed by them in the first place. <foreign>Sakābhyāsa praṇamyāsīt</foreign>: if you have followed the foot soles of the teacher within you, it is indeed <foreign>praṇamya</foreign>, i.e. the one who should be venerated properly (<foreign>səmbahən</foreign>). <foreign>Səmbahən</foreign> means: <supplied reason="subaudible">someone</supplied> that should be obeyed. The meaning is:</p>
. <p rend="stanza" corresp="#siksaGuru_05.04"><foreign>anāma hīnavākyam ahi siṁharūpañ ca grahaste, gurusaṁghāsanam pritam gr̥hate namaniṁmate</foreign>.</p>
. <p n="3" corresp="#siksaGuru_05.05"><foreign>Anāma</foreign>: the name of the teacher is not obtained (i.e., not to be mentioned). <foreign>Hīnavākyam</foreign>: not speaking about the holy virtue,<note><foreign>tan paṅucap saṅ hyaṅ hayu</foreign>: the intended meaning of the author here may be that one should not speak about the holy virtue <foreign>to the elder</foreign>, but rather receive instructions about it from him.</note> not slandering<note>The reading <foreign>upata</foreign> in msC is noteworthy. In MdS, we also find the word <foreign>upat</foreign>, <foreign>ngupat</foreign> ‘to backbite, to slander’. The prohibition of backbiting the teacher also occurs in SMG 4.5.</note> the elder <supplied reason="subaudible">teacher</supplied>. <foreign>Siṁharupāñ ca grahaste</foreign>: <supplied reason="subaudible">you are</supplied> seen to show anger toward the teacher. It does not happen like that. <foreign>Saṅ guru saṁghāsanam pritam</foreign>: you have to be quick: if the teacher is met on the way, or if the meeting happens in his own territory, the teacher should be revered. Also, not to speak impetuously to the teacher, let alone to precede the teacher’s steps, not being in a hurry (?, <foreign>avurugan</foreign>) when you take a bath, not to step in the shadow of the teacher, not seeking the refuge<note>I choose to normalize <foreign>paṅəban</foreign> into <foreign>paṅhəban</foreign>. However, this form is not recorded under the entry <foreign>hə̄b</foreign> in OJED. </note> from the teacher, not drinking the <foreign>tvak</foreign> of the teacher, not smelling the food of the teacher. Do not use the utensils<note>My understanding of <foreign>agəm-agəman</foreign> is in the light of SMG 12.2, which translates this word into OS as <foreign>papakaraṅan</foreign> ‘utensils’. Cf. the quasi synonym <foreign>gagaman</foreign> ‘arm, weapon’.</note> of the teacher, unless it is asked. One should not be careless with the wife of the teacher, children of the guru, father and the senior of the teacher, possession (<foreign>pesi</foreign>)<note> I interpret <foreign>pesi</foreign> as possession, based on one of the meanings of <foreign>esi</foreign> ‘possessing’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>isi</foreign>). In OS context, e.g. SKK 12.6 <foreign>əsi imahna</foreign> (litt. content of the house) refers to a ‘wife’.</note> of the teacher, nephew of the teacher, or the teacher’s beloved ones, and the teacher’s abandoned wife.<note>In OJED, the word <foreign>tadinan</foreign> is only attested in BK 39.16 <foreign>vuriniṅ kurən tadinan iṅ mahas maṅə̄</foreign> “After the husband’s departure she was abandoned to wander musing”. However, it is also attested in SS 46a <foreign>tan parabi valu-valuniṅ guru, valu-valuniṅ anaknira riṅ dharma, tadinan kunaṅ</foreign>.</note> As such is what is called the foot soles of the teacher; that should become the object of the attention of the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
. </div>
. <div n="6" corresp="#siksaGuru_06">
1190 <p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_06.01">This is the sixth affection of the teacher to the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>. How is it? As follows: what is called the holy Misfortune of the World. How is it? As follows: bad meets its bad, good meets its good, crooked meets its crooked, straight meets its straight, joy meets its joy. What is indeed the condition of happiness and sorrow of all beings? It is you, not anyone else, the pure circle of three bodily domains. The meaning is: because from the action, speech, and heart is the joy, and the joy and sorrow. You know the cause of the bad conduct which is the cause of misfortune: that is why the good conduct is to be performed, so that <supplied reason="subaudible">it is</supplied> not affected by the misfortune. This is what is called the world of misfortune. It should be made the object of the attention of the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
. </div>
. <div n="7" corresp="#siksaGuru_07">
. <p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_07.01">There is the seventh affection of the scholar to the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>. It is called the holy four powers (<foreign>caduśakti</foreign>) of the scholar.<note>See chapter 11, §Four Powers of the Teacher, on the explanation of this concept in Sunda and Java.</note> What is the reason why it is called <foreign>caduśakti</foreign>? The four powers mean its powers. They are used as weapons by the scholar. What are they? As follows: the formula (<foreign>cakra</foreign>)<note>In the present context, the word <foreign>cakra</foreign>, which means ‘wheel’, seems to refer to a supernatural weapon. I interpret this word as ‘formula’. The Idea of this is that the <foreign>cakra</foreign> possessed by the teacher englobe the whole world. The same Idea seems to occur in <foreign>Brahmāṇḍapurāna</foreign> 124.17, where the expression <foreign>cakra-paricakra</foreign> seems to mean ‘to wander about’ (OJED, s.v.): <foreign>kepvan ta bhaṭṭārī mahīsiki, cakra-paricakra kumuliliṅ ri paryantanikaṅ lokāloka, janaloka, tapoloka, satyaloka, brahmaloka</foreign>.</note> of <foreign>jalakuna</foreign>,<note>The word <foreign>jalakuna</foreign> is not attested elsewhere, except in SMG, which is a direct transmission of SiGu. In the explanation of this term below, it refers to the power of the teacher at the edge of the bottom world, before moving up to the ocean (<foreign>cakra jalapakṣa</foreign>). I wonder whether the meaning of the hybrid Sanskrit-Old Javanese compound <foreign>jalakuna</foreign> is ‘the ancient water (ocean)’, from <foreign>jala</foreign> ‘water’, and <foreign>kuna</foreign> ‘formerly, in olden times, before’ (OJED, svv.).</note> the formula of <foreign>jalapakṣa</foreign>,<note>From the explanation, we learn that <foreign>jalapakṣa</foreign>, only attested in SiGu and SMG, is the power of the scholar that causes misfortune to the spiritual practitioner in the ocean. I interpret <foreign>jalapakṣa</foreign> as ‘having water (ocean) as wings’.</note> the formula of arrangement (or: multitude?, <foreign>sambharaṇa</foreign>),<note>All manuscripts read <foreign>sambhirana</foreign>, which is incomprehensible in a sense. The text has presumably been corrupt since the earlier transmission. The closest word which seems suitable in the present context is Skt. <foreign>sambharaṇa</foreign> ‘putting together, composition, arrangement’, but glosses in OJED <foreign>sambarana</foreign>, ‘modest, simple, not overdone, unassuming’. Another possibility is to understand it as an error of Skt. <foreign>samīraṇa</foreign> ‘wind’, which seems more appropriate for the corresponding weapon (<foreign>cakra</foreign>)</note> the formula of the arm like stars (<foreign>taraṅgabāhu</foreign>).<note>The fourth power of the scholar is <foreign>taraṅgabahu</foreign>, which literally means ‘having arms like stars’?. Based on the explanation in the following paragraph, we can see that the order of four powers are ascending according to the place where the power is effective, from the bottom world (under the ocean) up to the edge of the upper world. The term used for each should be understood within this conceptual framework.</note></p>
. <p n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_07.02">As follows are the kinds of misfortune <supplied reason="subaudible">brought</supplied> by the scholar upon those who undertake spiritual practice. <supplied reason="subaudible">If</supplied> the one who undertakes spiritual practice dances at the bottom, the <foreign>jalakuna</foreign> is the means of the scholar to <supplied reason="subaudible">cause</supplied> misfortune at the edge of the bottom-world to the one who undertakes spiritual practice at the bottom. At the bottom, four are those<note><foreign>i svar pat ri saṅ mānadhana, ri patalapala</foreign>: the phrase is dubious. Does <foreign>pat</foreign> go along with <foreign>ri saṅ manādhana</foreign> or with <foreign>svar</foreign>? I prefer the first option, since we have an evident parallel in the following sentence: <foreign>patnikaṅ saṅ manādhana</foreign> and <foreign>patniṅ saṅ mānadhana</foreign>. The number four seems to imply the four directions (<foreign>lvar kidul kulvan vetan</foreign>) occupied by <foreign>saṅ manādhana</foreign>, not only in the middle world, but also in the bottom and upper world.</note> who undertake spiritual practice in the bottom-world; they dance in the sea, diving in the whirlpool of the ocean. <foreign>Jalapakṣa</foreign> is the means of the scholar <supplied reason="subaudible">to cause</supplied> misfortune to the ocean. Four among those who undertake spiritual practice from the ocean, they dance in the north, south, west, and east. The cakra sambharaṇa is the means <supplied reason="subaudible">to cause</supplied> misfortune of the scholar to the north, south, east, and west. Those <supplied reason="subaudible">who undertake spiritual practice</supplied> dance at the edge of the upper part: the formula taraṅgabahu is the means of the scholar <supplied reason="subaudible">to cause</supplied> misfortune to the edge of the upper part. The edge of the upper part is vanished, burnt, conquered by the weapon of the learned master—below, above,<note>Here we have <foreign>luhur</foreign> along with <foreign>ruhur</foreign>. Zoetmulder notes that <foreign>luhur</foreign> occurs along with <foreign>ruhur</foreign> in later texts such as <foreign>Koravāśrama</foreign>, <foreign>Tantu Paṅgəlaran</foreign>, and <foreign>Pārthayajña</foreign>, but in <foreign>kiduṅ</foreign>s, we find <foreign>luhur</foreign> exclusively (OJED, s.v. <foreign>luhur</foreign>).</note> and all around horizontally.</p>
1195 <p n="3" corresp="#siksaGuru_07.03">As follows are the kinds of the four powers that serve as a weapon of the scholar. The world and the whole universe are filled by weapons. The meaning is: be diligent in action, be diligent in speaking, be diligent in breathing, in order not to be affected by misfortune. It is what is called the holy four powers, that is the instruction of the scholar, that should be made the object of the attention of the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p>
. </div>
. <div n="8" corresp="#siksaGuru_08">
.<p n="1" corresp="#siksaGuru_08.01">Here, as follows would be the true meaning of what I will tell to a man like you, a man who causes the realization of the one who wishes to know his gods and their high value, the holy supreme <foreign>dharma</foreign>, and the beginning and the end of the current human life. That is the reason why one obtains the holy doctrine of the jewel (<foreign>ratnopadeśa</foreign>) originating from the reverend elders. There are what are called the three pacified bodily acts. You should be striving for them and should really pay attention to them,<note>My emendation is based on the occurrence of <foreign>sukha-duhkhanikaṅ janma samaṅke</foreign> in the same paragraph, a phrase that is an equivalent of <foreign>mūla patiniṅ janma samaṅke</foreign>.</note> for those are the origin of the bad and good, joy and sorrow of the current human life. You see people who are killed, beheaded; their father and mother are plundered and sold, their relatives are enslaved, their fathers are dragged into fields. What is the reason for this? The lack of diligence in practicing the holy three pacified bodily acts. The meaning is: without practicing it, they obtained sin and great misery. If you would speak like this: “Just in the same way, o Sir, <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> are affected by misfortune from that, the holy pacified bodily acts indeed … the life/humans, that is why <supplied reason="subaudible">there is</supplied> limitless pain, and misfortune in the world”. Likewise indeed, sir, <supplied reason="subaudible">you</supplied> are affected by misfortune from it. <supplied reason="subaudible">When</supplied> the holy pacified bodily acts <supplied reason="subaudible">are possessed by</supplied> the humans, that is the reason why <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> are not affected (<foreign>pahiṅan</foreign>) by the great misfortune in his world. Those <supplied reason="subaudible">words</supplied> are probably what I would say to you.</p>
.
1200<p n="2" corresp="#siksaGuru_08.02">I would say to you as follows: there is what is called pacified thought, pacified act, pacified speech. The pacified thought means a good mind, not plotting against people and not causing the sorrow of other people, let alone not causing chaos in the world. That is what is called pacified thought. The pacified act means the proper deeds, good deeds, correct deeds, not chastising <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> not causing harm to people. That is what is called the pacified act. The pacified speech means good words that are pleasant to hear by the people, not causing the extreme sorrow of other people, especially with one’s words. That is called pacified speech. <foreign>Tri</foreign> means the three: the pacified act <supplied reason="subaudible">is</supplied> to make people’s mind at ease.
